Incident Title: Example: Failed Login Spike from Single IP
Description: Multiple failed login attempts detected from IP address X.X.X.X
Containment Actions: Blocked IP address at WAF level; reviewed logs for successful authentications from same IP (none found); verified no account compromise
Root Cause: Brute force attack attempt from external IP; WAF rate limiting eventually blocked
Lessons Learned: WAF rate limiting working as designed; consider lowering threshold for failed authentications
Notes: False alarm - legitimate user with forgotten password after 3 attempts would have been acceptable; confirmed malicious via IP reputation check

Description: GuardDuty detected unusual API activity from EC2 instance
Containment Actions: Isolated EC2 instance (modified security group to deny all traffic); created snapshot for forensics; reviewed CloudTrail for unauthorized API calls
Eradication Actions: Terminated compromised instance; launched clean replacement from approved AMI; rotated IAM instance role credentials; scanned other instances for similar IOCs
Recovery Actions: Verified new instance healthy; ALB routed traffic to healthy instances; monitored for 48 hours; no recurrence
Root Cause: Outdated application dependency with known RCE vulnerability; patch not applied timely (exceeded 30-day SLA for high-severity vulnerabilities)
Lessons Learned: Improve vulnerability management; automate dependency scanning in CI/CD pipeline; monthly AMI rebuild schedule strictly enforced; GuardDuty worked excellently
Notes: ACTION ITEMS: Implement Dependabot; scheduled monthly AMI rebuilds in calendar; enhance monitoring for unusual outbound connections

Incident Title: Example: Accidental S3 Bucket Public Exposure
Description: Developer accidentally set S3 bucket public while testing; detected by Config rule
Detection Method: AWS Config Rule Violation â†’ Security Hub
Containment Actions: Immediately restored bucket to private (public access block re-enabled); reviewed access logs to determine if any external access occurred (none found); verified no data downloaded
Eradication Actions: Removed test bucket (not needed for production); updated developer training on S3 security; added pre-commit hook to scan Terraform for public buckets
Root Cause: Human error during development; lack of automated checks for Terraform security
Lessons Learned: PREVENTION: Add tfsec and Checkov to pre-commit hooks (implemented); require peer review for all Terraform changes (already policy; reinforce); developer re-trained on S3 security
Notes: False alarm severity - test bucket with synthetic data; treated as P2 for training purposes and procedure validation
